messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] taxes  OT
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/9/04 2:10:03 PM, tjreynoso@yahoo.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/9/04 2:10:03 PM, tjreynoso@... writes:

<< Are homeschoolers allowed to deduct the costs for supplies like

software and art and books on their taxes? Are we considered

educators by law if we have to file a letter of intent with the

county?


Sorry, but I didn't know who else to ask. >>

Unless you're taking someone else's money to teach their child, I don't think
so.

If you're running a school that has income, your expenses weigh against that
income. But not just for educating your own child, as I understand it.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] taxes  OT
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/9/04 4:09:48 PM Eastern Standard Time, ... If you are talking about federal tax form 1040 line 23 educator expense, the book says
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/9/04 4:09:48 PM Eastern Standard Time,
tjreynoso@... writes:

> Are homeschoolers allowed to deduct the costs for supplies like
> software and art and books on their taxes?

If you are talking about federal tax form 1040 line 23 educator expense, the
book says "Qualified expenses do not include expenses for home schooling..."
from the tax booklet pg. 29
Pam G


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: taxes  OT
messages.msgSnippet: Are homeschoolers allowed to deduct the costs for supplies like software and art and books on their taxes?  Are we considered educators by law if we have to
messages.messageBody:
Are homeschoolers allowed to deduct the costs for supplies like
software and art and books on their taxes? Are we considered
educators by law if we have to file a letter of intent with the
county?

Sorry, but I didn't know who else to ask.

Tanya
